body_html:
@4F2E4A2E It does match the standard case as in it was installed satisfying all requirements in the Docs and with the code you provided that generated error for you on PowerShell.
If you're referring calling pip globally or using the script it won't make any difference whatsoever.

So the unsupported wheel error you received is due something wrong on your side and not a TensorFlow bug neither related to PowerShell.
One case for instance is if you have more than one Python installation besides 3.5 64-bit generating conflicts with pip as it may be linked not to 3.5 but to other version, therefore requiring to use pip3. I am not sure if this is your situation.

The only thing I didn't test was to use a conda environment on PowerShell.

If you're referring calling pip globally or using the script it won't make any difference whatsoever.

One case for instance is if you have more than one Python installation besides 3.5 64-bit generating conflicts with pip as it may be linked not to 3.5 but to other version, therefore requiring to use pip3. I am not sure if this is your situation.
The only thing I didn't test was to use a conda environment on PowerShell.
body:
@4F2E4A2E It does match the standard case as in it was installed satisfying all requirements in the Docs and with the code you provided that generated error for you on PowerShell. 
If you're referring calling pip globally or using the script it won't make any difference whatsoever. 

So the unsupported wheel error you received is due something wrong on your side and not a TensorFlow bug neither related to PowerShell. 
One case for instance is if you have more than one Python installation besides 3.5 64-bit generating conflicts with `pip` as it may be linked not to 3.5 but to other version, therefore requiring to use `pip3`. I am not sure if this is your situation.

The only thing I didn't test was to use a conda environment on PowerShell.
